newsitem.title: FINLAND: PROTOS SAYS FINLAND NEEDS TIGHTER MONETARY POLICY.
newsitem.headline: PROTOS SAYS FINLAND NEEDS TIGHTER MONETARY POLICY.

text.p: Finnish monetary policy should become tighter as inflation will accelerate, and the best way to tighten monetary policy would be to let the markka appreciate, brokerage Davy Protos said in a report received on Tuesday.
"The strong Finnish growth outlook is inconsistent with the current combination of low nominal interest rates and an undervalued currency," Protos said.

"This kind of monetary policy will lead to higher inflation," it said, adding: "It is ... obvious that there is a clear need to tighten monetary policy. The best way to do this would be by an appreciation of the markka."
Protos painted two scenarios; in the first, the markka would be kept in a narrow band near its ERM midpoint -- this would lead to demand inflation.
"We calculate that inflation would rise to 2.8 percent," Protos said, referring to the year-on-year rise in December, "and spike to 4.0 percent at the end of 1998," it said.

In the second scenario, Protos expected the Bank of Finland to let the markka "move closer to its long run equilibrium level." The markka would appreciate 5-10 percent before the end of 1997. Inflation would accelerate to 2.0 percent by the end of this year and to 2.5 percent in 1998, it said.

"The Bank of Finland underlying inflation indicator would rise by only two percent," Protos said, noting that the central bank's need to tighten monetary policy by raising interest rates would be "markedly lower with a stronger currency."
